article_title: Katy home to growing senior community
article_text:
Katy home to growing senior community Nearly 39,000 residents over age 60 call the area home

At age 84, Erwin Engel is happy with the life he's lived so far. His college years at Texas A&M University, his career selling paper across the state and his 40-year marriage to Beatrice Louise Bryan, his late wife, are all highlights. So when he wakes up sore from arthritis pain in his room at the new Orchard Assisted Living and Memory Care in Katy, he doesn't let it get him down.

article_metadata.description: [...] when he wakes up sore from arthritis pain in his room at the new Orchard Assisted Living and Memory Care in Katy, he doesn't let it get him down.  Engel is one of nearly 39,000 residents over the age of 60 living in the Katy area, a community with a growing presence that can be seen in the construction of new assisted-living facilities, the location of home health care companies and the expansion of senior programming options.  Though the area has earned a reputation for its schools and strong jobs - the Katy Independent School District is expected to hit nearly 100,000 students by 2024, according to demographic reports - it's also home to a growing senior citizen community that represents roughly 10 percent of the population within the school district's boundaries.  The Katy area isn't as gray as Houston, where some 14 percent of the population is over 60, or even other suburbs including Sugar Land and The Woodlands, but it has an expanding number of living options for older residents.  Companies that track the senior housing market indicate that the area has more than doubled its stock of assisted-living and nursing-care facilities in the past five years, while census figures show the population of residents over age 60 grew by roughly 13,000 during that time.  Increasingly, the young family-oriented suburb could see more people like Engel, who decided to stay in the area, or older relatives choosing to live near the new families moving in.  After serving in the Army during the Vietnam War, McRoberts went home to start the rest of his life.  [...] as the health care options and living facilities expanded, it seemed like the better option.  The Katy area "has got much more - shopping, entertainment, doctors, nursing homes and assisted-living centers," she said.
article_metadata.author.name: By Leah Binkovitz
